title: berg_katse
body:
One of the main antagonists from the [[Gatchaman]] series.

[b]Berg Katse[/b] is an [[androgynous]] looking costumed villain.

title: zor
body:
A very advanced humanoid [[alien]] race from [[choujikuu_kidan_southern_cross|The Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 80s. 

The main antagonists in the show, the [b]Zor[/b] (ゾル, [i]Zo-ru[/i]) are at war with the human colonies from [[planet Glorie]].

h4. See also

* [[Bioroid]]
* [[Demi_(choujikuu_kidan_southern_cross)|]]
* [[Dera_(choujikuu_kidan_southern_cross)|]]
* [[Dess_(choujikuu_kidan_southern_cross)|]]
* [[Seifriet Weisse]]
other_names: ゾル人(超時空騎団サザンクロス)

title: lio_convoy
body:
The leader of the [[maximal|Cybertrons]] in [[Beast Wars II]]. He is a noble leader who cares deeply for his subordinates and often puts his life at risk for their sake. He transforms into a white lion based on [i]Kimba the White Lion[/i].

Official toy releases in the west vary on his name, some leaving the original Japanese name of Lio Convoy, while others have translated his name to Leo Prime.

title: rick_(splatterhouse)
body:
Main protagonist of the [[Splatterhouse]] horror and action [[video game]] series.

[b]Rick Taylor[/b], is a young man who has, through his fusion with a supernatural Evil Mask, become extremely muscular and super-humanly strong. 

He resembles to a great degree [[Jason Voorhees]], of the [[Friday the 13th]] movies.

title: mannings
body:
A fictional male character from the [[Orguss 02]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 90s.

[b]Mannings[/b] is a veteran [[military]] [[officer]] with [[blonde hair]] and a [[mullet]]. 

He is a cynical and opportunistic womanizer, but he is also quite good-hearted.

His character design is similar to (and was inspired by) [[Roy Focker]] from [[Macross]] and [[Sleggar Law]] from [[Gundam]].

title: sword_of_protection
body:
A fictional [[sword]] from the [[Masters of the Universe]] franchise. It first appeared in the [[She-Ra Princess of Power|She-Ra: Princess of Power]] cartoon from 1985.

The [b]Sword of Protection[/b] is a very ancient and magical weapon that holds many secret and fabulous powers. It is very similar to the [[Sword of Power]], but has an ovoid gem embedded in its blade. It also is virtually indestructible.

This sword is [[She-Ra]]'s weapon of choice.

title: mim-31_karyovin
body:
A fictional [[fighter jet]] from the [[MACROSS]] franchise. It first appeared in the [[Choujikuu Yousai Macross]] anime series from 1982.

The [b]Mikolev MiM-31 Karyovin[/b] fighter jet is an advanced delta wing combat aircraft developed by the [[Anti-U.N.]] Forces as their answer to the [[F203 Dragon II]] jet deployed by the [[U.N. Spacy]] early in the [[macross_zero|U.N. Wars]]. 

Using most of the same materials, the Karyovin was a comparable aircraft and was a step ahead of the conventional combat jets of its time. 

In real life this jet was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the early 80s.

title: black_jack_(series)
body:
A series created by [[Tezuka Osamu]] depicting the titular super [[surgeon]] character [[black_jack_(character)|Black Jack]] as he saves people with his incredible (and almost super-human) medical skills. 

It is the third most popular manga of Tezuka's behind [[Tetsuwan Atom]] and [i][[Jungle Taitei]] (Kimba the White Lion)[/i].

According to the "God of Manga" Tezuka (who in real life was actually also a medical [[doctor]] himself), Black Jack is the ideal type of physician he wished he had been. 

h4. See also

* [[Pinoko]]

title: vf-9
body:
A [[mecha]] from the [[Macross]] series. It appears in the [[Macross M3]] [[Sega Dreamcast]] [[video game]] from 2001.

The [b]VF-9 Cutlass[/b] is a small, fast and agile [[variable fighter]] with forward-swept wings. 

It was originally designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the late 80s as "VF-X-10" in "Advanced Valkyrie", a variable fighter [[toy]] line from Bandai. When the line wasn't produced he kept the design and used it years later in the console [[video game]]. 

Later it also appeared in [[Macross The Ride]] and [[Kanou Akira]]'s "Macross 7th Code.":http://www.mangaupdates.com/series.html?id=76482 

h4. See also

* [[YF-19]] - A later variable fighter with similar wing configuration

title: vf-19
body:
[[Variable fighter]] from the [[Macross]] [[mecha]] anime series. It appears in the [[Macross 7]] TV series as well as the [[video game]]s [[Macross VF-X]] and [[Macross VF-X2]]. 

The [b]VF-19 Excalibur[/b] is the production-line version of Shinsei Industries' [[YF-19]] AVF Prototype from [[Macross Plus]]. Readily recognizable by its forward swept wing configuration and high-dihedral [[canards]] aft of cockpit.

It was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the 90s.

h4. See also

* [[Fire Valkyrie]]

title: vfx-4
body:
Prototype for the [[VF-4]] [i]Lightning III[/i] variable fighter. It first appeared in the [[Choujikuu Yousai Macross]] series from the 80s.

In [[real life]] it was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]].

title: yf-25
body:
A mecha from the [[MACROSS]] universe. 

The [b]YF-25 Prophecy[/b] is the prototype of the VF-25 variable fighter from [[Macross Frontier]].

In [[real life]] it was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]].

h4.See also

* [[VF-25]]

title: moaramia_jenius
body:
A character from the [[Macross]] universe. She appears in the [[Macross M3]] [[Sega Dreamcast]] [[video game]].

Moaramia is the adopted [[Zentradi]] daughter of [[Maximilian Jenius]] and [[Millia Jenius]]. Her original Meltrandi name was [b]Moaramia Jifon[/b].

She is also a highly skilled [[Meltrandi]] ace. Her [[mecha]] of choice is the Variable [[Glaug]].

title: vf-14
body:
The [b]VF-14 Vampire[/b] is a variable fighter [[mecha]] that appeared in the [[Macross M3]] [[video game]]. 

It also appeared (in a heavily modified form) as the [[Fz-109a]] [[Elgerzorene]] in the [[Macross 7]] anime series.

In [[real life]] it was created by [[Kawamori Shouji]] for the game and the series.


h4. See also:

*  [[Fz-109a]] [[Elgerzorene]]

title: vf-27
body:
A fictional [[mecha]] from the [[MACROSS]] universe. The [b]VF-27 Lucifer[/b] is an advanced [[variable fighter]] that first appeared in the [[Macross Frontier]] anime TV series from 2008.

This [[variable fighter]] is so fast and agile that only [[cyborg]]s can tolerate its maximum speeds.

It is the mecha of choice for [[Brera Sterne]].

In [[real life]] it was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]].

h4. See also

* [[Macross Galaxy]]

title: ikaruga
body:
[b][i]Ikaruga[/i][/b] is a top-down shoot-em-up produced and scored by Iuchi Hiroshi of [[Treasure (developer)]].  

It's considered the spritual successor to [[Radiant Silvergun]], despite its minimalist ruleset. The key feature is the duality system where you can switch between white and black and absorb the bullets of your current colour.  

The [[Sega Dreamcast]] version has a backstory about [spoilers]some guy who got shot down and the assassin sent to kill him who joined his cause.[/spoilers]

h4. Characters

* [[kagari (ikaruga)|Kagari]]
* [[shinra (ikaruga)|Shinra]]

title: phalanx_(destroid)
body:
A [[mecha]] from the [[MACROSS]] series. It first appeared in the [[Choujikuu Yousai Macross]] TV anime [[science fiction]] series from 1982.

The [b]SDR-04-Mk XII Phalanx Space Defense Robot[/b] [[destroid]] is a main battle robot system (mecha) created by the [[U.N. Spacy]] to fight the [[Zentradi]]. It was the final destroid developed during Space War I and it was designed to act as a fleet defense mecha.

Armed with dozens of missiles in two large cylindrical launchers, the Phalanx made an excellent semi-mobile [[missile]] based battery. Some variants also featured defensive armaments such as a head mounted [[gatling gun]]. 

During the last battles of Space War I against the Zentradi [[alien]] fleets, the Phalanx units were repainted and refitted to fire long-range "reaction" ([[radiation symbol|nuclear]]) warheads for use against the enemy alien [[space]] warships.

In [[real life]] the Phalanx was designed by [[Miyatake Kazutaka]] in the early 80s.

title: mazinger_z:_infinity
body:
[b][i]Mazinger Z: Infinity[/i][/b] is a 2018 [[science fiction]] [[super robot]] anime film released to celebrate the 45th anniversary of the [[Mazinger Z]] franchise.

It is directed by Shimizu Junji and premiered in Japan in January 13, 2018.

h4. See also

* [[Mazinger Z Infinity]] (robot)

title: cy-kill
body:
Main antagonist sentient variable [[robot]] of Tonka's [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Cy-Kill[/b] is the extremely evil, sinister and psychopathic leader of the GoBot Renegade faction. His alternate mode is a blue, white and red [[motorcycle]].

Cy-Kill is based on [[Bike Robo]], a heroic character in "Popy":[https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%83%9D%E3%83%94%E3%83%BC_(%E7%8E%A9%E5%85%B7%E3%83%A1%E3%83%BC%E3%82%AB%E3%83%BC)]'s [[Machine Robo]] 600 Series (the earliest line of the toys).
The original Bike Robo and other Machine Robo 600 members appeared as supporting characters in the 80s anime [[Machine Robo Chronos no Gyakushuu]].

When Tonka was bought by Hasbro in 1991, like [[Transformers]], the brand was acquired by Hasbro as well. Since then, the poor Gobots—especially Cy-Kill—haven't been very fortunate.

The denizens of Japanese [[Futaba Channel]] imageboard managed to "import" the notorious "Transformers kill Gobots" joke to their community — although only to one of their four servers.

The two memes below originated from Futaba:

* Meaningless jargon トンカは即そぉい! ("Tonkaz should get dumped ASAP!")
* Cy-Kill who speaks in the same tone of voice as [[father_(shinsei_motemote_oukoku)|Father]] ([[Shinsei Motemote Oukoku]]). They insist that Cy-Kill's face that was adapted to look "evil" in the cartoons, looks just like Father.

title: j_(final_fight)
body:
An antagonist [[video game]] character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]J[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He has [[blonde hair|blonde]] [[spiked hair]], wears a yellow jacket with a [[radiation symbol]] on its back and blue baggy [[jeans]]. His design is basically a palette swap of [[Two P]].

These characters are infamously difficult to beat because in the game, they tend to strike when the player has their back turned on one of them, and they appear among crowds of enemies most of the time.

title: mome_(orguss)
body:
A female character from the [[Choujikuu Seiki Orguss]] [[mecha]] anime [[science fiction]] TV series from the 80s. 

[b]Mome[/b] (モーム [i]Mōmu[/i]) is [spoilers]a [[mu_(orguss)|Mu]] [[android]] with a small girl's body. She is actually responsible for salvaging and repairing [[Taii]], whom she reprogrammed to be an ally to the crew of the [i]Glomar[/i] [[Emaan]] ship.[/spoilers]

title: qf-3000e
body:
A [[mecha]] from the [[MACROSS]] series. It first appeared in [[Choujikuu Yousai Macross]] TV series from 1982.

The [b]QF-3000E Ghost[/b] is an unmanned [[robot]] aerospace fighter used by the [[U.N. Spacy]] to fight the [[Zentradi]] [[alien]]s. 

h4. See also

* [[Ghost Drone]]

title: f203_dragon_ii
body:
A fictional [[fighter jet]] from the [[Macross]] franchise. It first appeared in the [[Choujikuu Yousai Macross]] anime series from 1982.

The [b]McNell Douglar F203 Dragon II[/b] fighter jet is an advanced delta wing combat aircraft developed by the OTEC research institute and adopted as the main fighter of the [[u.n._spacy|U.N. Forces]] in 2003. 

Built as a delta wing aircraft with [i]OverTechnology[/i], the F203 was stronger, faster and more efficient than previous fighter aircraft. 

The craft was much more maneuverable than conventional fighter jets and was light despite equipment for V/STOL capabilities. 

[[Roy Focker]] flew an F203 during his service as a fighter pilot in the [[macross_zero|United Nations Wars]].

In [[real life]] the jet was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the early 80s.

title: riin_(orguss_02)
body:
A fictional male main character from the [[Orguss 02]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 90s.

[b]Riin[/b] (also translated as [b]Lean[/b]) is a young,  intrepid and adventurous (but somewhat naive) ancient Decimator mecha salvager. 

He has short [[brown hair]] and is very idealistic and proactive.

title: toria_(orguss_02)
body:
A fictional female character from the [[Orguss 02]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 90s.

[b]Toria[/b] is a young girl with short [[pink hair]].

title: olson_verne
body:
One of the main characters from the [[Choujikuu Seiki Orguss]] [[mecha]] anime [[science fiction]] TV series from the 80s. 

[b]Olson D. Verne[/b] (オルソン・D・ヴェルヌ [i]Oruson Dī Verunu[/i]) is a mecha fighter ace [[pilot]].

His name is a tribute to legendary actor/director "Orson Welles":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orson_Welles and classic science fiction writer "Jules Verne":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jules_Verne.

h4. See also

* [[Orguss Olson Type]]
other_names: オルソン・D・ヴェルヌ

title: road_ranger
body:
A sentient variable [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Road Ranger[/b] is an heroic member of the GoBot Guardian faction. His alternate mode is a blue, red and silver trailer [[truck]].

title: dive-dive
body:
A sentient variable [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Dive-Dive[/b] is an heroic member of the GoBot Guardian faction. His alternate mode is a dark blue and silver nuclear [[submarine]].

title: sword_of_power
body:
A fictional [[sword]] from the [[Masters of the Universe]] franchise. It first appeared in the original cartoon from the 80s.

The [b]Sword of Power[/b] is a very ancient and magical weapon from planet Eternia that holds many secret and fabulous powers. It is virtually indestructible.

This sword is [[He-Man]]'s weapon of choice.

h4.See also

* [[Sword of Protection]]

title: dianan_a
body:
A fictional female [[mecha]] from the [[Mazinger Z]] [[super robot]] series from the 70s created by [[Nagai Gou]].

[b]Dianan A[/b] (ダイアナンA - [i]Daianan Ēsu[/i]), also known as [b]Diana A[/b] is a giant female robot created by [[Doctor Yumi]] Gennosuke, [[Doctor Morimori]], [[Doctor Sewachi]] and [[Doctor Nossori]] with inspiration from Doctor Kabuto Juzou's designs. 

It is an improved and more combat capable version of [[Aphrodai A]].

Like Aphrodite, Diana A is armed with the [[breast_missiles|Oppai Missile System]], but can also shoot laser rays from its optical units (eyes).

title: aisha_(mospeada)
body:
[b]Aisha[/b] (アイシャ) is a female character from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 80s.

She is [spoiler]an [[Inbit]] [[alien]] in female humanoid form.[/spoiler]

Aisha was given the name [[Marlene_(Mospeada)|Marlene]] in the [[Robotech]] American adaptation.

title: billy_cool
body: A fictional playable male character from the [[Sunset Riders]] [[arcade]] [[video game]] released by [[Konami]] in the early 90s.

title: orguss_olson_type
body:
A [[mecha]] from [[choujikuu_seiki_orguss|The Super Dimension Century Orguss]] TV series.

The [b]Orguss Olson Type[/b] is an advanced variable mecha that can transform into 4 different modes which are [[starfighter|fighter]], [[gerwalk]], [[tank]] and giant robot mode.

[spoiler]It is a variant of the original [[orguss_(mecha)|Orguss]] made for [[Olson Verne]].[/spoiler]

In [[real life]] it was designed by artist [[Miyatake Kazutaka]] in the early 80s.

title: guld_goa_bowman
body: A male half-[[Zentradi]] character from the [[Macross Plus]] OVA released in the 90s.

title: gosu
body:
Fictional [[alien]] mecha from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] anime series from the 80s. 

The [b]Gosu[/b] is an advanced type of [[Inbit]] [[mecha]] designed exclusively for humanoid Inbit use.

title: street_heat
body:
A sentient variable [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Street Heat[/b] is an heroic member of the GoBot Guardian faction. His alternate mode is a red [i]Roadster[/i] [[car]].

His [[Machine Robo]] version was originally painted blue and black and adorned with fire stickers. The Japanese name of this variant is [b]Hot Rod Robo[/b].

title: bob_(sunset_riders)
body: A fictional playable male character from the [[Sunset Riders]] [[arcade]] [[video game]] released by [[Konami]] in the early 90s.

title: mylene_jenius
body:
One of the main characters from the [[Macross 7]] [[mecha]] anime series. 

[b]Mylene Flare Jenius[/b] (ミレーヌF ジーナス, Mirēnu F. Jīnasu) is one of the eight half-[[Zentradi]] ([[Meltrandi]]) daughters of [[U.N. Spacy]] captain [[Maximilian Jenius]] and his wife, Zentradi ace [[Millia Jenius]]. 

She is also a member of the "[[Fire bomber]]" rockband, of which main character [[Nekki Basara]] is also a member. Mylene is a [[bass guitar]] player and also an skilled variable aerospace [[aircraft]] and [[mecha]] [[pilot]]. 

Her mecha of choice is the [[VF-11 MAXL]] civilian variable aircraft.

h4. See also

* [[Guvava]]

title: dug
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Dug[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a [[dark skin]]ned head swap of [[Bred]] dressed in red. Dug is [[bald]] and also wears [[sunglasses]].

title: harrier_(character)
body: The main protagonist and playable character from the [[Space Harrier]]  [[science fiction]] [[video game]] produced by [[Sega]] in 1985.

title: mr._heli_(mecha)
body: The titular [[gerwalk]] [[mecha]] [[helicopter]] from the [[Mr. HELI]] 1987 [[arcade]] [[video game]].

title: crimson_b.a.t.
body:
A fictional [[robot]] from the [[G.I. JOE]] franchise.

The [b]Crimson B.A.T.[/b] ([i]Crimson Battle [[Android]] Trooper[/i]) is a variant of the [[Cobra B.A.T.]] clad in Cobra Crimson Guard uniform colors.

The Crimson B.A.T.s have enhanced combat programing and are even more lethal than the average Cobra B.A.T.s

The Crimson B.A.T.s are usually deployed in small numbers and assigned as bodyguards and escorts to selected Crimson Guard officers and high ranking [[Cobra Command]] elite officers and other selected members.

title: raramia_rerenia
body:
A character from the [[Macross Frontier]] [[mecha]] anime series from 2008. 

She is a silent female [[Zentradi]] ([[Meltrandi]]) [[S.M.S.]] pilot with short red hair and an intense gaze.

title: melda_deitz
body:
A fictional humanoid alien character from the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato]] military [[science fiction]] anime series. She appears in the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato 2199]] TV anime series from 2012.

[b]Melda Deitz[/b] is a [[brown hair]]ed and blue skinned [[Gamilas]] female ace [[starfighter]] pilot.

title: powered_gear
body:
[i][b]Powered Gear - Strategic Variant Armor Equipment[/b][/i] is a 1994 cooperative multiplayer beat'em up [[arcade]] [[video game]] produced by [[Capcom]]. 

It was released as [i][b]Armored Warriors[/b][/i] outside Japan.

This game is a prequel to [[Cyberbots]] (1995).

h4. See also

* [[Variant Armor]]

title: ideon_gauge
body:
A gadget from the epic [[super robot]] anime, [[Densetsu Kyojin Ideon]].

Circular or hemispherical screens placed on [[Ideon]]'s body, the cockpit of its each ABC-mecha and the bridge of [[Solo Ship]]. It can measure (can't control) Ide's unstable power level using symbolic glowing lines.

title: yaguchi_haruo
body: The main character from the [[High Score Girl]] comedy manga series from 2010.

title: vf-0s
body:
A transformable [[mecha]] from the [[Macross]] universe.

The [b]VF-0S[/b] is the [[commander]] version of the [[VF-0]] variable fighter equipped with two head-mounted [[laser]] cannons, a [[gunpod]] and several [[missiles]].

It was the mecha of choice for [[Roy Focker]] in [[Macross Zero]].

title: stella_(alex_kidd)
body:
Fictional female character from the [[Alex Kidd]] [[video game]] of [[SEGA]] fame. 

Wears a yellow and blue [[bodysuit]].

title: tom_(techno_police)
body:
A fictional sentient [[robot]] from the [[Techno Police 21C]] [[mecha]] anime film from 1982.

[b]Tom[/b] is a small [[Technoid]] [[Police]] robot [[dog]] equipped with sophisticated sensors and other detection equipment.

title: technoid
body:
A type of fictional [[robot]] from the [[Techno Police 21C]] [[mecha]] anime film from 1982.

The [b]Technoids[/b] are a type of advanced sentient [[Police]] robots equipped with powerful weaponry, sophisticated sensors and detection equipment, as well as heavy armor, according to their use. 

h4. See also

* [[Scanny]]
* [[Blader]]
* [[Tom (Techno Police)]]

title: night_fright
body:
A sentient variable [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Night Fright[/b] is an evil member of the GoBot Renegade faction. His alternate mode is a [[camouflage]]d [[Mi-24]] combat [[helicopter]].

title: vf-171
body:
Variable fighter [[mecha]] that appeared in the [[Macross Frontier]] TV series from 2008. It also appears in the later [[Macross Delta]] TV series from 2016.

The [b]VF-171 Nightmare Plus[/b] is the main New [[U.N. Spacy]] ([[N.U.N.S.]]) variable fighter during the events of Macross Frontier (2059). It is similar to the [b]VF-17 Nightmare[/b] from [[Macross 7]], but has a more advanced airframe and is easier to pilot and produce. It can be upgraded into the [b]VF-171 EX[/b] version, which was created to fight the [[Vajra (macross)|]]. 

The VF-171 was designed in [[real life]] by [[Kawamori Shouji]].

h4. See also

* [[VF-17]]

title: sue_graham
body: A fictional female character from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 80s.

title: scanny
body:
A fictional sentient [[robot]] from the [[Techno Police 21C]] [[mecha]] anime film from 1982.

[b]Scanny[/b] is a very advanced [[Technoid]] [[Police]] [[robot girl]] equipped with a sophisticated facial sensor unit composed entirely of blinking LEDs, and two connection cables streaming from the neck which plug into terminal sockets and enable her to interact with other computer systems.

title: blader
body:
A fictional sentient [[robot]] from the [[Techno Police 21C]] [[mecha]] anime film from 1982.

[b]Blader[/b] is an advanced [[Technoid]] [[Police]] robot equipped with built-in weaponry, increased agility, hyper speed and super strength.

title: upper_(ex-ranza)
body:
A supporting [[mecha]] from the [[Ex-Ranza]]/[[Ranger X]] [[video game]] released for the [[Sega Mega Drive]]/[b]Sega Genesis[/b] home console in 1993. 

The [b]Upper[/b] (アッパー, [b]Ex-Up Indra[/b] in the English version) is a powerful combat robot [[unicycle]] that helps the [[ex-ranza_(mecha)|Ex-Ranza]] [[mecha]] during its mission.

h4. See also

* [[Forge (Ex-Ranza)]]
other_names: アッパー(エクスランザー)

title: breast_missiles
body:
Also known as [b]Oppai Missiles[/b]. 

The [b]Breast missiles[/b] first appeared in the 1972 [[super robot]] manga (and its anime adaptation released in the same year) [[Mazinger Z]] by [[Nagai Gou]]. 

The female [[mecha]] [[Aphrodai A]] is the first character in the history of anime to display such ability.

title: tamtam_(samurai_spirits)
body:
A character from the [[Samurai Spirits]] [[video game]] series.

[b]Tam Tam[/b] is a renowned [[Maya (culture)|Maya]] hero from a village in [[Mexico]] (referred to as "Green Hell" in the game). His weapon of choice is the [i]Henge Hange Zange[/i] (ヘンゲハンゲザンゲ [i]Hengeru Hangeru Zangeru[/i]), a type of Maya [[machete]].

He is also [[Cham Cham]]'s big brother.

title: kuchiki_manabu
body:
[b]Kuchiki Manabu[/b], also known as [b]Kuchii[/b] (クッチー [i]Kucchī[/i]), is a loud, skinny and tall male [[otaku]] character from [[Genshiken]] with short [[black hair]] who loves karaoke, [[video game]]s, [[cosplay]] and anime.

While he is sometimes disliked by the rest of Genshiken (especially by the girls), Kuchiki is actually good hearted and has been very helpful in more than one occasion. 

Kuchiki is the classic cute-fixation otaku: he calls other female members with the -chin suffix, his movements and behavior copy those of many popular anime and most of the time he speaks imitating the voices of popular characters.

title: robotech:_love_live_alive
body:
American adaptation of the [[Mospeada]] OVA [[Love Live Alive]] modified to follow the continuity of the [[Robotech]] franchise. 

It was released in the West in 2013.

title: forge_(ex-ranza)
body:
A supporting [[mecha]] from the [[Ex-Ranza]]/[[Ranger X]] [[video game]] released for the [[Sega Mega Drive]]/[b]Sega Genesis[/b] home console in 1993. 

The [b]Forge[/b] (フォージ, [b]Ex-Up Eos[/b] in the English version) is a powerful combat robot [[starfighter|aerospace fighter]] that helps the [[ex-ranza_(mecha)|Ex-Ranza]] [[mecha]] during its mission.

h4. See also

* [[Upper (Ex-Ranza)]]
other_names: フォージ(エクスランザー)

title: yoshitake_risa
body: [[Yoshitake Rika]]'s tall and athletic sibling from the second season of [[Genshiken]].

title: misaki_youko
body:
Main protagonist of the [[Gowappaa 5 Godam]] [[super robot]] anime series from 1976.

[b]Misaki Youko[/b] is a notable character because she is actually the [b]first female protagonist of a super robot show in the history of anime[/b].

h4. See also

* [[Godam]]

title: godam
body: Titular [[mecha]] from the [[Gowappaa 5 Godam]] [[super robot]] anime series from 1976.

title: cham_cham
body:
A [[cat girl]] character from the [[Samurai Spirits]] [[video game]] series.

[b]Cham Cham[/b] comes from a [[Maya (culture)|Maya]] village in [[Mexico]] (referred to as "Green Hell" in the game). She is [[TamTam (Samurai Spirits)|Tam Tam]]'s younger sister.

Her weapon of choice is the [i]Yok Mok Mook[/i], a type of Maya [[boomerang]].

title: stick_bernard
body:
One of the main characters from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] [[mecha]] anime series from the early 1980s.

[b]Stick Bernard[/b] is a human Mars Base [[soldier]] bent on [[revenge]] against the alien [[Inbit]] invaders.

He is a 20-year-old Mars Base lieutenant who becomes stranded on Earth after the Inbit obliterate the defenses of the Second Earth Recapture Force he was part of.

Stick later leads a band of human rebels who fight against the aliens by using guerrilla tactics. Stick's mecha of choice is a green [i]VR-052F Battler[/i] [[Mospeada_(mecha)|]], which carries a [[beam rifle]] and forearm [[missile pod]]s. He is also a [[Legioss]] and [[Tread]] mecha ace pilot.

His name was changed to [b]Scott Bernard[/b] in the [[Robotech]] American adaptation of the series.
other_names: スティック・バーナード

title: great_mazinger
body:
The sequel to [[Nagai Gou]]'s anime/manga [[Mazinger Z]].
 
[i][b]Great Mazinger[/b][/i] (グレートマジンガー, [i]Gurēto Majingā[/i]) is a [[science fiction]] manga and [[super robot]]  [[mecha]] anime that features a [[great_mazinger_(robot)|new robot]] that is an improved version of the original [[mazinger_z_(mecha)|Mazinger]]. 

It was aired on Japanese television in 1974, immediately following the end of the first Mazinger series, and ran for 56 episodes.

h4. See also

* [[Tsurugi Tetsuya]]
* [[Honoo Jun]]
* [[Venus A]]

* [[UFO Robo Grendizer]]

title: sgt_hartman
body:
[b]Gunnery Sergeant Hartman[/b]

The antagonizing drill instructor made famous and popular in [[Full Metal Jacket]] played by character actor (and real life former [[Marine Corps]] drill instructor) "R. Lee Ermey":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R._Lee_Ermey .

title: proto_garland
body:
A transformable [[motorcycle]] from the [[Megazone 23]] [[cyberpunk]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 80s.

In [[real life]] it was designed by [[Aramaki Shinji]].

title: ex-ranza
body:
[b][i]Ex-Ranza[/i][/b] (エクスランザー), released outside Japan as [[Ranger X]], is a [[science fiction]] and [[mecha]] action side scrolling run and gun "shoot 'em up" [[video game]] for the [b]Sega Genesis[/b]/[[Sega Mega Drive]]. 

The game was developed by GAU Entertainment and published by [[Sega]]. It was released worldwide in 1993.

This title is notable because its graphics are so colorful and detailed some experts claim it is the only game that has broken through the Mega Drive hardware's colour limitations.

h4. See also

* [[Ex-Ranza (mecha)]]
* [[upper_(ex-ranza)|Upper]] / Ex-Up Indra
* [[forge_(ex-ranza)|Forge]] / Ex-Up Eos

title: ranger_x
body:
[[Ex-Ranza]] (エクスランザー), released outside Japan as [i][b]Ranger X[/b][/i], is a [[science fiction]] and [[mecha]] action side scrolling run and gun "shoot 'em up" [[video game]] for the [b]Sega Genesis[/b]/[[Sega Mega Drive]]. 

The game was developed by GAU Entertainment and published by [[Sega]]. It was released worldwide in 1993.

This title is notable because its graphics are so colorful and detailed some experts claim it is the only game that has broken through the Mega Drive hardware's colour limitations.

h4. See also

* [[Ex-Ranza (mecha)]]
* [[Upper (Ex-Ranza)]]
* [[Forge (Ex-Ranza)]]

title: otaple
body:
An [[otaku]] [[couple]]. 

Term introduced in the first season of the [[Genshiken]] anime TV series.

[i]Tag what you see:[/i] Only use this tag if the couple are shown to be otakus in that image.

title: akagi_ritsuko
body:
A character from [[Neon Genesis Evangelion]] who is [[Nerv|Nerv's]] head scientist, working along side [[Ikari Gendou]] ([spoilers]who she loved[/spoilers]). 

She is a workaholic and [[smoking|heavy smoker]], and has been friends with both [[Katsuragi Misato|Misato]] and [[Kaji Ryouji|Kaji]] since college.

title: great_mazinger_(robot)
body:
The titular [[mecha]] from the [[Great Mazinger]] [[super robot]] series from 1974.

It is piloted by [[Tsurugi Tetsuya]] and is an improved versión of the original [[Mazinger Z (mecha)]] made with a new and more resistant metal called [i]Super Alloy New Z[/i].

title: brera_sterne
body:
A character from the [[Macross]] series. He first appeared in the [[Macross Frontier]] TV series from 2008.

h4. See also

* [[Macross Galaxy]]

title: glaytork
body:
A sentient combat giant [[alien]] [[robot]] from the [[Karmatron y los Transformables]] franchise.

[b]Glaytork[/b] is a Cybernetic Gladiator from planet [[Metnal]] created for the sole purpose of destroying [[Karmatron]]. 

It was designed by a Metnalite scientist called [[Garkoz]] with advanced combat artificial intelligence and is armed with an anti-robot sword, an axe, ionic boomerangs and immobilizing nets. 

Glaytork's superstructure is ultra-reinforced and has programming for several different types of [[martial arts]]. The robot is 300 feet tall and does not possess variable geometry.

title: slash_(final_fight)
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Slash[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a very tall [[muscular]] bound thug who is able to defend oncoming attacks, unlike other opponents. He has dark [[curly hair]] and wears a dark [[leather jacket]], [[fingerless gloves]] and [[cowboy boots]]. His design is basically a palette swap of [[axl_(final_fight)|Axl]].

His name is a tribute to [[Guns N' Roses]] guitarist, [[slash_(guns-n-roses)|Slash]]. Apparently, some of the developers of Final Fight are fans of that band.

title: zsu-23-4
body:
The [b]ZSU-23-4 Shilka[/b] is a lightly armored, self-propelled, radar guided anti-aircraft weapon system (SPAAG) produced in [[Russia]] in the early 60s. It is still in use by both the Russian Army and the Navy.

It is named after the 'Shilka' river located in Zabaykalsky Krai, south eastern Russia.

title: axl_(final_fight)
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then. 

[b]Axl[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a very tall [[muscular]] bound thug who is able to defend oncoming attacks, unlike other opponents. He has shoulder-long [[blonde hair]] and wears a [[leather jacket]], [[fingerless gloves]], [[cowboy boots]] and a [[bandana]]. His design is a palette swap of [[slash_(final_fight)|Slash]].

His name is a tribute to [[Guns N' Roses]] vocalist, [[Axl Rose]]. Apparently, some of the developers of Final Fight are fans of that band.

title: sr-71_blackbird
body:
An American high-speed, high-altitude reconnaissance [[aircraft]] built by Lockheed in the 1960s.

With its blue-black paint job, full-length chines "[1]":[#dtext-external-links], long shock cone inlets and inward-canted tailfins (design consequences of an early attempt at stealth), the [b]SR-71 Blackbird[/b] has one of the most distinctive silhouettes of any aircraft.

Goes really, really fast (up to Mach 3.3) and is considered the fastest air-breathing manned [[military]] [[aircraft]] (but it is NOT a [[fighter jet]]).

h4. Related development

* [[M-21 Drone Carrier]]
* [[Lockheed D-21]] [[Drone]]

h4. See also

* [[List of Airplanes]]
* [[F-117 Nighthawk]]
* [[B-2 Spirit]]
* [[U-2 Dragon Lady]]
* [[XB-70]]
* [[MiG-25]] 

h4#external-links. External links

[1] Wikipedia: "Chines (SR-71)":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_SR-71_Blackbird#Chines

* Wikipedia: "SR-71":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_SR-71_Blackbird

title: wong_who
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Wong Who[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a rotund [[bald]] man with an eastern high-tied [[ponytail]] and a Fu Manchu [[mustache]], and also wears a white grandfather shirt with green pants and suspenders.

He is of Chinese descent.

title: appleseed
body:
An 80s [[science fiction]] manga created by [[Shirow Masamune]]. 

The series follows the adventures of ESWAT members [[Deunan Knute]] and [[Briareos Hecatonchires]] in Olympus, a fictional utopian city in the far future. 

Like much of Masamune's work, Appleseed merges elements of the [[cyberpunk]] and [[mecha]] genres with a heavy dosage of politics, philosophy, and sociology. 

The manga series spans four volumes, released between 1985 and 1989. 

It has been adapted into an OVA (1988), two animated films (released in 2004 and 2007), and a series of video games.

title: blade_(dragonninja)
body:
One of the two playable characters from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

[b]Blade[/b] is a street fighter with [[brown hair]] and a [[mullet]]. He wears black [[fingerless gloves]], a black [[tank top]], white [[jeans]] and dark and white [[converse]] [[sneakers]].

Despite what his external appearance could suggest he is actually an expert in martial arts and able to channel his inner energy (ki) in a devastating blow that can defeat several enemies at once.

Blade is a palette swap of [[striker_(dragonninja)|Striker]]. Because of their same physical features many fans have theorized that they may be twins.

title: striker_(dragonninja)
body:
One of the two playable characters from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

[b]Striker[/b] is a street fighter with [[brown hair]] and a [[mullet]]. He wears black [[fingerless gloves]], a black [[tank top]], green [[jeans]] and dark and white [[converse]] [[sneakers]].

Despite what his external appearance could suggest he is actually an expert in martial arts and able to channel his inner energy (ki) in a devastating blow that can defeat several enemies at once.

Striker is a palette swap of [[blade_(dragonninja)|Blade]]. Because of their same physical features many fans have theorized that they may be twins.

title: gowappaa_5_godam
body:
[b][i]Go-wapper 5 Go-dam[/i][/b] (ゴワッパー5ゴーダム [i]Gowappā Faibu Gōdamu[/i]) is a 70s [[super robot]] anime series that first aired in 1976. There were 36 episodes. It is also referred to as [b][i]Godam[/i][/b] and [b][i]Gowapper 5 Gordam[/i][/b].

This [[science fiction]] series is notable because it was the [b]first super robot anime to feature a female as the leader and main character[/b]. 

h4. See also

* [[Godam]]
** [[Misaki Youko]]

title: sg-1000_mark_ii
body:
The [b]SG-1000 Mark II[/b] (エスジー・セン [i]Esujī Sen II[/i]), also known as the [b]Sega Game 1000 Mark II[/b], was a cartridge based [[video game]] home [[game_console|console]] manufactured by [[Sega]] and released in Japan, Australia, and other countries in the early 80s. 

The console was released in July 1984 as an improved version of the original [[SG-1000]] console from a year before. It featured a few hardware tweaks from the original model, including detachable [[gamepad]]s and the ability to play Sega Card games. 

The Mark II did not sell well, however, leading to Sega's decision to continue work on its video game hardware. This would result in the release of the Sega Mark III in Japan in 1985, which later became the [[Sega Master System]] worldwide.

title: sega_sc-3000
body:
The [b]SC-3000[/b], also known as the [b]Sega Computer 3000[/b], was a cartridge based [[video game]] home [[game_console|console]] and personal [[computer]] hybrid manufactured by [[Sega]] and released in Japan, Australia, and other countries in the early 80s. 

The console was released as a Pc version of the original [[Sega SG-1000]] console. It featured a built-in keyboard. It was later upgraded as the [b]SC-3000H[/b] some time later.

title: daicon_33
body:
A revival project celebrating the 33 anniversary of the creation of the [[Daicon III]] and [[Daicon IV]] anime shorts.

[[Gainax]] revealed the details of [b]Daicon 33[/b] on January 8, 2014. The concept of the project is "the revival of [[DAICON]] FILM" and the company plans to release various goods inspired by their early short films from the 80s. 

The project's official site has started accepting pre-orders for the first lineup of the memorial goods including a towel and clear file featuring the girls from the famous Daicon Ⅲ & Ⅳ opening animations. The new illustration is drawn by [[Akai Takami]], the character designer of the opening animation films and one of the founders of Gainax. The illustration is now also displayed on the top page of Gainax's official site.

The project is also offering an iPhone case, tote bag, and mug cup featuring Daicon Ⅲ inspired art.

h4. See also

* "'Daicon 33' Oficial Site" [s]h[/s][s]ttp://www.gainax.co.jp/daicon33/[/s]

title: va-3
body:
A transformable [[mecha]] from the [[Macross]] universe. It first appeared in promotional material for the [[Macross Plus]] OVA from 1994 and has since been included as part of the franchise, appearing in several different publications and toy lines of the Macross saga during the years.

The [b]Northrom Grumman VA-3 Invader[/b] is a Variable Attacker (VA) airframe mass produced for the [[u.n._spacy|UN Forces]] for ground suppression with the special characteristics of both a [[Variable Fighter]] (VF) and a [[Destroid]] mecha.

The VA-3 was designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the 90s for the Macross Plus series, but was not used in the OVA and thus never animated. The [i]Invader[/i] first appeared on pages 72-73 of the promotional book [i]This Is Animation Special: Macross Plus[/i] from 1995. Its variants, the VA-3C Custom (VA-3C Kai) appeared in OVA series [[Macross Dynamite 7]] and the VA-3M appeared in [[Macross VF-X2]].

h4.See also

* "Wikipedia article (JP)":[https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/VA-3_%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%83%99%E3%83%BC%E3%83%80%E3%83%BC]

title: centurions:_power_xtreme
body:
[i][b]Centurions: Power Xtreme[/b][/i] is a syndicated 30 minute American [[science fiction]] animated television series produced by Ruby-Spears in the 80s.

The show is notable because it was actually animated in Japan by famous animation company [[sunrise_(company)|Sunrise]]. 

American comic book legends "Jack Kirby":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Kirby and "Gil Kane":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gil_Kane contributed to the design and concepts of the show.
 
The series began in 1986 as a five-part miniseries and was followed with a 60 episode series. The series was story edited by Ted Pedersen and written by several authors, including prolific science fiction writers Michael Reaves, Marc Scott Zicree, Larry DiTillio and Gerry Conway. 

The series theme and soundtrack were composed by Udi Harpaz. There was also a line of tie-in toys by Kenner and a comic book series by [[DC Comics]].

h4. Characters

* [[Crystal Kane]]
* [[Ace McCloud]]

h4. See also

* "Wikipedia article":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Centurions_%28TV_series%29]

title: daltanious
body:
The titular [[mecha]] from the [[Mirai Robo Daltanious]] [[super robot]] anime series from the late 70s.

[b]Daltanious[/b] was the first combining [[gattai]] super robot with an animal component and the first with a [[lion]]'s head on its chest. 

The lion's head would be incorporated later into several Brave Series robots, including [[GaoGaiGar]] from the 90s.

title: buki_ninja
body:
A type of antagonist [[ninja]] from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

The [b]Buki ninjas[/b] are a ninja enemy variant from the game that specializes in armed combat. 

They have red outfits and usually attack using [[kunai]] daggers or [[nunchaku]], which can be retrieved from them after being defeated. Energy replenishing drinks and time items are also left behind by them after being taken down.

Like the [[Nage ninja]]s, Buki ninjas also tend to attack alone most of the time.

title: orko
body:
A fictional [[alien]] character from the [[Masters of the Universe]] franchise. He first appeared in the original cartoon from the 80s.

[b]Orko[/b] is a very small floating [[wizard]] with blue skin and big pointy ears. He wears a red tunic, a red pointy hat and his face is covered in a purple scarf, so only his eyes can be seen.

title: animal_(dragonninja)
body:
One of the end of level bosses from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

[b]Animal[/b] is a huge [[armor]]ed enemy with many muscles, red [[facepaint]] and a [[mohawk]]. He is as slow as he is powerful but also not very smart.

title: dairugger_xv_(mecha)
body:
ダイラガーXV (Dairugger Fifteen)

The titular [[gattai]] [[mecha]] from the [[Kikou Kantai Dairugger XV]] anime series.

The heroic anime [[super robot]] consists of the largest number of separate [[mecha|mechas]] ([[Rugger 1]] ~ [[Rugger 15]]). (Some "evil":http://wiki.cre.jp/SRW/%E3%82%B4%E3%83%83%E3%83%89%E3%83%8D%E3%83%AD%E3%82%B9 or parody combined robots from other anime series have many more constitutive units).

Like so many other 70s~80s super robots, it was designed by industrial designer  "Murakami Katsushi.":http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/encyclopedia/people.php?id=9769

title: smallfoot
body:
A sentient variable female [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Smallfoot[/b] is an heroic member of the GoBot Guardian faction. Her alternate mode is a red [i]Toyota Hilux[/i] pick-up [[truck]].

title: crasher
body:
A sentient variable female [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Crasher[/b] is an evil member of the GoBot Renegade faction. Her alternate mode is a black, red and white Porsche 959 sports [[car]].

title: tsugumo_ryoko
body: A fictional female character from the [[Area 88]] manga and anime series from the 80s.

title: toby_masuyo
body:
[b]Toby "Kissy" Masuyo[/b] (トビ・マスヨ [i]Tobi Masuyo[/i]) is one of the main protagonists of the [[Baraduke]] scrolling [[science fiction]] shooter arcade [[video game]] from the 80s. 

Toby predated by one year [[Samus Aran]] from [[Metroid]] as the first human female playable character in a Sci-Fi game. 

Toby also appears in the [[Mr. Driller]] game series as a minor character and in the [[PlayStation 2]] game [[Namco X Capcom]].

She was called "FIGHTER" or "KISSY" until [[Mr. Driller]] was released. ("KISSY" was originally a nickname of Japanese game creator "Kishimoto Yoshihiro.)":https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%B8%E6%9C%AC%E5%A5%BD%E5%BC%98

title: brain_powered
body:
[b]Brain Powerd[/b] (ブレンパワード, Buren Pawādo?) is a Japanese mecha anime television series created by [[Sunrise]] in the 90s.

It was directed and written by [[Gundam]] creator [[Tomino Yoshiyuki]]. The series features [[mecha]] designs by [[Nagano Mamoru]], character designs by Inomata Mutsumi, and music by Kanno Yoko.

The 26-episode Brain Powerd television series originally premiered across Japan on the sattelite channel WOWOW between April 8 and November 11, 1998. The series was also aired across Japan on the anime network Animax, which also later broadcasted the series across its respective networks worldwide, including its English language networks in Southeast Asia and South Asia. 

Animax aired Bandai Entertainment's localization, the series' English language television premiere. The anime series was licensed by Bandai and distributed across the region on DVD under the English title [[Brain Powered]]. 

The series was also adapted into a manga, with art by Sugisaki Yukiru, which was serialized in Japan's Kadokawa Shoten magazine Shōnen Ace and later published in the United States in English by Tokyopop. A series of light novels, music CDs, and other merchandise relating to Brain Powerd also exist.

title: solzie
body: A female character from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] [[mecha]] anime series from the 80s.

title: bad_boy_(gobots)
body:
A sentient variable [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Bad Boy[/b] is an evil member of the GoBot Renegade faction. His alternate mode is a green [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] attack [[jet]].

title: sorceress_(he-man)
body:
A fictional female character from the [[Masters of the Universe]] franchise. She first appeared in the original cartoon from the 80s.

[b]Sorceress[/b] is the magical mistress, gatekeeper and overseer of [[Castle Grayskull]]. She has many magical powers and is responsible for taking care of the [[sword_of_power|power swords]] of Grayskull.

Sorceress has an outfit with feathers and a helmet similar to a [[falcon]]'s head.

[spoiler]Sorceress is the real mother of [[Teela]], but she gave her daughter in adoption to Duncan, also known as [[Man-At-Arms]], to be able to fulfill her duty as guardian of Grayskull.

title: sexy_(srungle)

title: inbit_hive
body:
A fictional [[alien]] installation from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] TV anime series from the 80s.

The [b]Inbit Hive[/b] is a type of organic [[Inbit]] installation that, as its name implies, serves as a hive or base to a great quantity of Inbit units.

title: dolly_(srungle)
body: One of the protagonists from the [[science fiction]] [[mecha]] anime TV show [[Akuu Daisakusen Srungle]] from the 80s.

title: princess_farla
body:
[b]Princess Fala[/b] or [b]Farla[/b] (ファーラ姫 [i]Fāra-hime[/i]) is a fictional female character from the [[hyakujuu-ou_golion|GoLion]] [[mecha]] anime TV series form the early 80s. Renamed [b]Princess Allura[/b] or [b]Allura[/b] in the [i]Voltron[/i] dub. 

Takes over piloting the [[Ao-jishi]] after the death of [[Shirogane Takeshi]].

title: holly_wood
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Holly Wood[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a palette swap of [[El Gado]]. He sports a goatee, wears a beige suit and a [[bandana]] on his head. 

In some occasions, he comes dressed in red and brandishing [[molotov cocktail]]s, which he throws at the heroes just before leaving. This version is much weaker than usual, and requires only one hit to be killed off.

title: jake_(final_fight)
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Jake[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He is a bearded [[brown hair]]ed thug who dresses similar to [[Bred]] and [[Dug]], only his outfit is blue and he wears also a [[vest]].

title: hard_corps:_uprising
body:
[b]Hard Corps: Uprising[/b] is a [[Contra]] [[video game]] developed by Arc System Works and published by [[Konami]]. It is a prequel to the old [[Contra Hard Corps]] shooter from the [[Sega Mega Drive]] released in the mid 90s.

The game was released on Xbox Live Arcade in February 16, 2011 and on the PlayStation Network in March 15, 2011.

title: mig-25
body:
A high-speed, high-altitude "interceptor":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interceptor_aircraft designed by the Soviet Mikoyan-Gurevich bureau in the 1960s to counter the threat of [[xb-70|fast, high-flying intruders]].

The [b]MiG-25[/b] (NATO reporting name [b]'Foxbat'[/b]) is a large, heavy [[aircraft]] built mainly around its two massive turbojets. Recognition features include a long ogival radome, a small, streamlined canopy, rectangular air intakes, twin vertical fins, sharply raked tailplanes, and the presence of small ventral fins near the engine exhaust. 

Armament consists only of two to four R-40/AA-6 'Acrid' air-to-air missiles.

Despite its low maneuverability and primitive avionics is still considered the highest flying and fastest [[fighter jet]] ever built.

h4. See also

* [[MiG-31]]
* [[F-15 Eagle]]
* [[Viktor Ivanovich Belenko]]
* [[SR-71 Blackbird]]
* [[XB-70]]

h4. External links

* Wikipedia: "MiG-25":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-25
* Youtube: "Mikoyan MiG-25 Foxbat video":http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJzFxSRa5y0

title: belger
body:
A character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] videogame from the late 80s, where he is the main antagonist and the game's final boss.

[b]Belger[/b] is the leader of the [[Mad Gear]] gang. He is a [[bald]] and strong middle aged man with a [[beard]] who is bound to a motorized [[wheelchair]]. His main weapon is the [[crossbow]].

title: diapolon
body:
Protagonist [[gattai]] super robot(?) from the [[UFO Senshi Dai Apolon]] 70s anime series, characterized by its American football-themed design.

In the show the mecha is actually not "piloted" by [[takeshi_(dai_apolon)|Takesh]], but  doing "fusion" with him.
other_names: ダイアポロン(巨大ロボ)

title: xb-70
body:
The [i]North American Aviation[/i] [b]XB-70 Valkyrie[/b] was an experimental, large bomber jet made for a USAF requirement of a  nuclear-armed, deep-penetration strategic bomber for the Strategic Air Command of the U.S. Air Force during the 60s. Only two were built. 

The Valkyrie was a very advanced for its time six-engine bomber aircraft jet with [[canards]] capable of reaching Mach 3+ while flying at 70,000 feet (21,000 m). Its maiden flight was on 1964.

The program was canceled due to cost overruns, changing needs of the air-force, improvements in high-altitude surface-to-air missiles (SAMs), the introduction of intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs) to the U.S. nuclear arsenal and the unfortunate mid air collision of one of the prototypes with an [[F-104 Starfighter]].

The remaining one served as a research plane for NASA before being retired to the National Museum of the United States Air Force in 1969.

h4. See also

* [[MiG-25]] - A [[Soviet]] [[fighter jet]] designed to intercept it.
* [[VF-1]]

title: tasc-02-scf_logan
body:
A [[mecha]] from the [[Choujikuu Kidan Southern Cross]] mecha anime series from the 80s.

The [b]TASC-02-SCF "Logan"[/b] is a small, fast and agile aerospace variable mecha used by the [[TASC]].

It is armed with a triple barreled ion cannon on its nose and a small energy [[gunpod]]. It can also carry a limited amount of [[missile]]s. 

Its mecha form resembles a [[VF-1]] in [[Gerwalk]] mode.

title: marlene_(mospeada)
body: The [[Robotech]] alternate name of the character [[Aisha (Mospeada)|Aisha]] from the [[Kikou Souseiki Mospeada]] 80s [[mecha]] anime series.

title: bred
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

[b]Bred[/b] is part of the original [[Mad Gear]] gang that terrorized the streets of [[Metro City]]. He exemplified the look of a typical Mad Gear thug. It was his car that got trashed in the bonus round of Final Fight I and [[street_fighter_iv_(series)|Street Fighter IV]] (when playing as [[Cody Travers]]). 

Bred wore a light brown suit and had dirty blond [[short hair]]. His design was based on the main antagonist from an 80s action/musical movie called [i]Streets of Fire[/i], played by American actor Willem Dafoe.

title: xf/av-01_silph
body:
A fictional advanced combat [[jet]] [[aircraft]] that appears in the [[Kuhga]] [[Science fiction]] arcade [[video game]] released by [[Data East]] in the late 80s, and also in one of its sequels from the 90s, [[Kuhga Gaiden]].

The [b]XF/AV-01 Silph[/b] is an advanced fighter jet that possesses balanced weaponry and speed. It is best suited for beginners or novices to the game.

title: vt-1_super
body:
A transformable [[mecha]] from the [[Macross: Do You Remember Love?]] animated [[science fiction]] film from the 80s.

It is a [[space]] combat training version of the [[VF-1]] equipped with Super Packs.

Designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]].

title: dragonninja_(character)
body:
The final boss of the [[Dragonninja]] martial arts arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

The [b]Dragonninja[/b] is the evil leader of a powerful legion of [[ninja]] who are the main antagonists during the game. He wears ancient japanese [[armor]], an [[oni mask]] and is armed with a [[kunai]] dagger and several fire [[shuriken]].

title: edi_e
body:
An antagonist videogame character from [[Capcom]].

He first appeared in the [[Final Fight]] game from the 80s, and in many other fighting games since then.

The corrupt [b]Edi E.[/b] is a big and fat [[police]] officer with a [[mustache]] (or [[beard]] in some production and promotional art) who is in the payroll of the evil [[Belger]] and helps the original [[Mad Gear]] gang terrorize the streets of [[Metro City]]. 

He is a tough end of level boss and the only character in the game who uses a firearm.

title: koutetsu_jeeg_(mecha)
body: The titular [[super robot]] from the [[Koutetsu Jeeg]] anime TV series from the 70s.

title: spay-c
body:
A sentient variable female [[robot]] of the [[GoBots]] franchise from the 80s.

[b]Spay-C[/b] is an heroic member of the GoBot Guardian faction. Her alternate mode is a white and black [[space shuttle]].

Her original Japanese design was male and is actually called [b]Space Shuttle Man[/b].

title: nikick
body:
A fictional transforming [[mecha]] of [[choujikuu_seiki_orguss|The Super Dimension Century Orguss]] TV series.

The [b]Nikick[/b] is an advanced variable combat mecha that is usually assigned to officers and aces in the [[Chiram]] military. 

The Nikick is very fast and highly maneuverable. It is armed with several [[rocket launcher]]s, inbuilt autocannons and a powerful energy [[gunpod]].

It was designed by [[Miyatake Kazutaka]] in the early 80s.

title: srungle_(mecha)

[b]Sukeji Yabu[/b] is a character from the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato]] science fiction anime series from the 70s. 

He also appears in the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato 2199]] remake from 2012, where his name was changed to [b]Sukeharu Yabu[/b].

title: shultz
body:
A character from the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato]] sci-fi anime series from the 70s. He also appears in the [[Uchuu Senkan Yamato 2199]] series from 2012.

[b]Shultz[/b] (also known as [b]Valke Schultz[/b]) is a "second class" [[alien]] [[Gamilas]]/[[Gamilas]] [[Commander]] from the Pluto frontline base.

title: vf-3000
body:
A mecha from the [[Macross]] series. The [b]VF-3000 Crusader[/b] is a heavy variable fighter [[mecha]] featured in the [[Macross M3]] [[Sega Dreamcast]] videogame.

It is basically a bigger/heavy fighter version of the original [[VF-1]] [b]Valkyrie[/b].

It was originally designed by [[Kawamori Shouji]] in the late 80s for a variable fighter [[toy]] line from Bandai. When the line wasn't produced he kept the design and used it years later in the console [[video game]].

title: maya_nonderaiko
body:
A character from the [[Honneamise No Tsubasa]] (Wings of Honneamise) [[Science fiction]] animated film from the 80s.

[b]Maya Nonderaiko[/b] is a short haired girl who was adopted by [[Riquinni Nonderaiko]].

title: scopedog
body:
[b]ATM-09 Scopedog[/b]
[[Mecha]] from the 80s anime series [[soukou_kihei_votoms|Armored Trooper Votoms]]. While simplistic, it possesses many variants with added armament and performance. Its most distinctive feature is its triple-sensor visor, which requires the pilot to wear a specific type of helmet, which became heavily associated with one of its most known pilots, the stoic [[Chirico Cuvie]].

It was designed by [[Ookawara Kunio]].

title: dougram
body:
The titular [[mecha]] from the [[Fang of the Sun Dougram]] 80s anime TV series.

It was designed by [[Ookawara Kunio]].

title: zako_ninja
body:
A type of antagonist [[ninja]] from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

The [b]Zako ninjas[/b] are the most common type of enemy in the game. They wear blue ninja costumes and are experts in [[martial arts]], usually moving very fast and attacking with kicks, flying kicks, punches and acrobatics.

Zako ninjas are always deployed in vast numbers, but they are actually very weak and a single strike is enough to defeat them.

title: nage_ninja
body:
A type of antagonist [[ninja]] from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

The [b]Nage ninjas[/b] are a ninja enemy variant from the game that specializes in long range combat. 

They have dark grey outfits and usually attack throwing [[shuriken]]s, [[makibishi]] and exploding ninja bombs. Nage ninjas tend to attack alone most of the time.

title: kabuto_(dragonninja)
body:
A type of enemy [[ninja]] from the [[Dragonninja]] [[martial arts]] arcade [[video game]] from the 80s.

The [b]Kabuto[/b] are a ninja antagonist variant from the game that specializes in sword combat. 

They have different colored outfits and usually attack by using [[katana]] swords and very high multiple jumps. 

Like the [[Nage ninja]]s and the [[Buki ninja]]s, Kabuto ninjas also tend to attack alone most of the time.

title: xfv-03_seylen
body:
A fictional advanced combat [[jet]] [[aircraft]] that appears in the [[Kuhga]] [[Science fiction]] arcade [[video game]] released by [[Data East]] in the late 80s, and also in one of its sequels from the 90s, [[Kuhga Gaiden]].

The [b]XFV-03 Seylen[/b] is an advanced fighter jet that possesses superior speed and maneuverability, but is lightly armored. As such, it is best suited for skilled players who have more experience with the game.

title: elita_one
body:
A character from the [[Transformers]] science fiction franchise.

[b]Elita One[/b] is an heroic [[Autobot]], a sentient alien female [[robot]] that can transform into a pink and silver Cybertronian sport [[truck]].

She is the powerful and brave leader of the female Autobot resistance faction in [[Cybertron]]. 

Before becoming leader of the female Autobots, Elita [spoiler]used to be a smaller robot called [[ariel_(transformers)|Ariel]]. Se was mortally damaged by Megatron, but Alpha Trion reconstructed her into the ultimate powerful form of Elita One.[/spoiler]

Her name is a tribute to the titular character of a [[soviet]] sci-fi film from 1924 called [i] "Aelita, Queen of Mars":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aelita .[/i]

Motto: [i]"Elita One knows no fear...!!!".[/i]

h4. See also

* [[Optimus Prime]]

title: ariel_(transformers)

Ariel is a heroic [[Autobot]], a sentient alien [[robot]] that can transform into a pink, purple and white [[Cybertron]]ian car.

She is [spoiler] [[Elita One]]'s early weaker protoform.[/spoiler]

title: dela_delon
body:
Primary antagonist (and later playable character) of the [[Brandish]] series. Also effectively the "mascot" character, as she is featured extensively on box and cover art.

Dela has [[long hair|long]], [[wavy hair|wavy]] [[blonde hair|blonde]] hair and [[blue eyes|blue]] (sometimes [[purple eyes|purple]]) eyes. She is usually depicted wearing purple [[bikini armor]] with [[gold trim|gold-trimmed]] purple [[pauldrons]] and a [[purple cape]]. She also wears [[purple gloves|purple]] [[elbow gloves]] and [[purple footwear|purple]] [[thigh boots]], both with white [[fur trim]].

Dela also carries a metallic [[mage staff]] tipped with a socketed crystalline purple [[orb]].

The overall impression of Dela's appearance is basically a "black magician girl" sorceress. Dela is a magic user, and her chief motivation in chasing down the protagonist [[Ares_(brandish)|]] is to avenge the death of her master.

h5. Alternate names
* Alexis [tn]Localized name in the English SNES version of the first Brandish.[/tn]
* Dora Doran [tn]Transliterated name in Brandish: The Dark Revenant.[/tn]

title: snap-fit_buckle
body:
Also known as a side release buckle. This buckle is made out of plastic, where one half is made up of 3 prongs that seamlessly join together with the other half that acts as a shell. The buckle is released by pressing on the sides to push the prongs inward.

A "snap" noise is created when you connect the buckle together and when you pull it apart.


h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Side release buckle":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckle#Side_release_buckle]
